reviewText: I'm so bored with todays reality TV world and I may be old fashioned but I long for shows with some kind of history story anything with substance. I have not seen Daniel Boone since a kid but remember I loved it and started with season two and I will soon own the whole five seasons. the only minor complaint I have is I wish the episodes would just keep running into each other. i work third shift and do fall asleep with them going and the choosing each episode every 45 minutes gets old just let them flow. But overall the quality and packaging and information is wonderful and this and Band of Brothers are my two best box sets. Wish there was more TV and movies from this  early 1800's timeframe but we have computer generated super heros and dumb remakes and and survivor that are all stupid enough to power todays viewer ratings. Thank god the good stuff is being remastered and boxed together for some kind of sanity break
summary: Great set old wonderful Show Boy do I miss Good TV like this

reviewText: I remembered a lot of things from the series, and one was that I loved the ones with Mingo the best. When I saw that season one was black and white, I decided not to order it...although I may do so later.  But season two is just a delight.  Mingo is always so cool...and it has enough episodes that are more about family relationships, slavery issues, and less about fighting. There's plenty of that, too, though...if you're into snarking at the Friench - and our British ancestors. :-)  Little Israel is so cute! Interesting to see Veronica Cartright as Jemima, sister to Angela Cartright from Lost in Space.  I didn't remember her! I really enjoyed watching the episodes commercial free, and the color and clarity are perfect.  If you look up Daniel Boone in Wikipedia, you soon find out that this whole series has taken great liberties with the real Daniel Boone's life, but I love the show and Season Two is highly recommended.
Title: N/A

reviewText: DANIEL BOONE-SEASON TWO: It may not have boasted DAVY CROCKETT's hit single status, but the catchy theme song claimed, "DANIEL BOONE was a man...yes a BIG man"...series head FESS PARKER topped out at six and a half feet, a clear case of truth in advertising. The former star of WALT DISNEY's phenomenally successful CROCKETT didn't even have to change coonskin caps for his long-running follow up hit. This fairly violent program featured the brave frontiersman, explorer, and occasional Indian fighter protecting the settlers of Boonesborough, including his sensible wife REBECCA, teen daughter JEMIMA and young son ISRAEL. Semi-regular cronies in later seasons included country warbler/future pork sausage king JIMMY DEAN, character actor ALBERT SALMI and ex-footballer ROSIE GRIER...but it was singer ED AMES' sensitive portrayal of cultured half-Cherokee MINGO who proved almost as popular as PARKER himself. Part western, part action/adventure series, DANIEL BOONE may have been technically inaccurate in order to fit in every historical visitor imaginable, but there was always a moral to be had when the big man laid down his rifle.RATING: FOUR COONSKIN CAPS
Title: N/A

reviewText: I just finished watching the last two episodes of this season. It's great that it's in color. However, the last quarter of season 1 they abandoned the character of Yadkin. They didn't even write him out of the show. They keep Albert Salmi's name in the credits until the end of season 1 but he's not there at the end. They abandoned a few other of the people who live in and around the settlement too, like the future grandma Walton, who was featured in several season 1 episodes. At the end of this season, there is also a two part 'revisionist' episode retelling how the Kentucky settlement came to be. In season 1, Boone, married and already with his two kids, is asked by the patriots to go scouting in Kentucky for a place to build a new fort. He goes on foot with Yadkin and they meet Mingo when they save him from Mohawk Indians. He then helps Boone in the rest of the season 1 pilot. Later Boone and his family and a bunch of other settlers move through the Cumberland Gap, build a fort and a settlement. All that was the premise in season 1. At the end of season two in this two-part episode, they say that Daniel Boone, single and leading a group of covered wagons, are out as "pioneers" going to settle in Kentucky. No fort, no Indians, it was a joke of an insult to season 1. They did meet Mingo in this season ending "new revisionist pilot" but in different circumstances. I just want to know why? They obviously went to great thought and effort to revise this aspect of the show, what did they think the fans would think? I just want to know why. I just pretend, and advise new watchers of this season to just pretend that the last two episodes don't exist. Overlooking these problems, the show is still a good show to watch with the revolutionary war in the background of the plot occasionally spilling out west into Kentucky. They have the character Jericho Jones in this season, and I couldn't stand him. Kept waiting for him to get scalped or shot and written out. Maybe next season. Missed Yadkin even more. The theme music also changed somewhat, a variation of the original version with less banjo and more emphasis on acoustic guitar. A livelier version, it was just as good as the original music I guess. The episodes were not quite as original and historical or action filled as episode 1 but as I said still worth watching as only one of a couple of colonial era tv shows ever made. Fess Parker basically carries this season, and his family, Ed Ames, and Cincinnatus.
summary: Good but not as good as season 1

reviewText: I used to watch this as a kid and I remembered it as being very good.Well, I was afraid it might not, but it does hold up over time.Season 1 isn't as good, I watched a few of those and I was disappointed. But I figured maybe the 2nd season was better, and it turns out I was right.The stories are much better in this 2nd season, and now I am looking forward to the 3rd and 4th seasons, as well!Oh, and I didn't see this mentioned anywhere - no one seems to be making a big deal about it - but this season 2 set contains a 2 part episode at the end, on the last disc, which shows how Dan'l met Mingo and his wife. It must have been the series pilot or something, I'm not sure. Maybe it says somewhere but all I know is that it seemed weird that they put it at the end of Season 2 when it seems like it should have been at the beginning of Season 1 - except that it's in color. Is it possible they did go back and create this at the end of Season 2? kind of a flashback??Anyway, this 2-parter's quite good (though it partially steals the plot of an old Western with Jimmy Stewart), and was a nice extra at the end of the set.

reviewText: I have been told Fess Parker was not that great an actor (some say Buddy Epsen carried him in Davy Crockett), well 6 seasons of Daniel Boone say otherwise! He did a great job in both the Disney Davy Crockett series and Daniel Boone show. The show is truly excellent and often commands a high price for DVDs of each season. The stories are entertaining but not always as accurate as they should be (i.e., the Aaron Burr Story, etc.), which is a minor disappointment. I am very happy with this purchase and hope to acquire more seasons of this outstanding series, if I can find them at a fair price.

reviewText: Yes, I'm old so I remember watching Daniel Boone as a kid but my children and grandchildren certainly hadn't.  I gave this 2nd season to my grandkids for Christmas this year.  We all watched the first two shows off the first disc together.  My 12 year old (boy) just laughed at the antics and thought it was hokey.  My 4 (girl), 9 (girl) and 10 (boy) year old LOVED them.  So when we took a road trip to FL after Christmas, the kids brought along this set of tapes.  The 9 and 10 year old watched (on dvd player) most of the shows during the ride there and back (from OH).  The 4 year old and 9 year old now sing Daniel Boone's theme song daily.  The kids have really enjoyed watching these shows.  I don't find it hokey (different from what's on tv now) but this is a clean show and that's what I was wanting.  I'll buy more seasons, too (from Amazon).  fyi:  the 12 year old has watched all of them, too -- he has been won over!
summary: Mixed reviews from kids but I loved it!
Title: N/A

reviewText: My wife bought Daniel Boone Season 1 a year or two ago as a gift and forgot about it. She poppped it out at Christmas time and I remembered watching DB as a teen. Well I forgot how well this series was made. I liked season 1 so much I ordered season 2&3 about half way through season 1. I have just finished season 2 and started season 3. The series has evolved for the better. Even though I have half a MBA, I learned some things from American Colonial History I hadn't known about. I find these stories great. They always have a moral foundation and demonstrate family values with action and some humor. Fess Parker I grew up with as a little boy with his Davy Crockett Dismey series in the movies. Yes, I got the (man made materials)coonskin cap and enjoyed sining the Title song. Daniel Boone actualy was related to Davy Crockett as a great uncle I believe. If you like wilderness America like I do with the likes of Last of the Mohicans ala Randolph Scott, or Hawkeye from the late 50's TV show, you will love Fess Parker as Daniel Boone and Ed Ames as Mingo. Factoid:  TV's Richard Boone(Have Gun will Travel) is a direct descendant of Daniel Boone. Hope this helps enjoy:)Phil

reviewText: Just got Season 2 from Amazon and it looks great!  Since my family had a B&W; TV when I was growing up--until my older sister bought us a color TV with her own money--this is actually my first time seeing "Daniel Boone" in color.  It doesn't look much like Kentucky, but whatever part of California they filmed it in sure is pretty.As with season 1, the acting is still good.  Kind of miss Yadkin, but everyone else is back.  My sons (ages 12 & 10) love this show as much as I do, proving that you don't have to be crass to attract the modern kids--just tell good stories.One last thing, were Jemina's eyes really that blue or is that a trick of the restoration?
